DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Chief Criticizes Party's `Negligence'
Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Urbanek criticizing his Communist Party for making mistakes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party chief Karel Urbanek today said the party leadership had made mistakes marked by ``negligence and irresponsibility'' that led the organization into its worst crisis. Speaking to 1,500 delegates at a special party congress, Urbanek also admitted his own guilt as a member of the ruling Politburo in allowing hated hard-liners to remain in the party leadership. The party was expected to purge its ranks of many discredited party leaders during the two-day meeting. The Communists have been rocked by two shake-ups in the leadership to remove hard-liners and the loss of thousands of members since the country's peaceful pro-democracy movement began four weeks ago, changing the political orientation of the country. The congress, called to determine the party's future in the wake of a revolution that swept a government led by non-Communist into office, scrapped all its party statutes, which could pave the way for a comprehensive organizational reform. Party spokesman Josef Hora told reporters the congress also decided to divide the leadership duties between a general secretary and a party chairman. Former Premier Ladislav Adamec, who resigned earlier this month after failing to reach agreement with the opposition on a new government, was thought to be a contender for one of the posts, according to congress observers who spoke on condition of anonymity. On Nov. 24, the party ousted hard-line leader Milos Jakes and others responsible for the crackdown on the ``Prague Spring'' reforms of 1968, and Urbanek replaced Jakes as party chief. The much despised Prague party boss, Miroslav Stepan, was ousted two days later in a further leadership reshuffle that brought unknown Communists to the top. Stepan's ouster was demanded by massive protest rallies. Both Jakes and Stepan were later expelled from the party for ``serious political mistakes.'' They had refuted assertions by a parliamentary commission that they were politically responsible for a Nov. 17 police crackdown on peaceful student demonstrators that ignited the ensuing democratic revolution. Urbanek said the ``party leadership manifested negligence and irresponsibility worthy of punishment.'' ``With self-criticism, I admit my part of the guilt in'' leaving Stepan on the Poliburo, Urbanek said, adding that the decision was ``an extraordinary, politically serious mistake.'' Outlining the crisis now faced by the party, Urbanek noted that it had lost 66,290 of its 1.7 million members in the last month. Urbanek also revealed that the party faces bankruptcy, disclosing that party dues were used to build recreation facilities for the top brass ``about which the rank-and-file only learned today.'' The speech confirmed the total disarray in which the party finds itself following the triumphs of the pro-democracy movement. The most recent victory came on Tuesday as the Communist-dominated Parliament gave the new reform government a vote of confidence, and endorsed opposition leader Vaclav Havel for president. ``There is no doubt that the congress delegates have the duty ... to take the party out of its deepest crisis ever,'' the Communist Party daily Rude Pravo said in a front-page editorial today. Havel, a former dissident who emobdies the democracy movement, said on the eve of the party congress that the party should become ``a modern political party which would participate as an equal among equals in the pluralistic system...'' Urbanek told Prague congress delegates Tuesday night that new elections to the Politburo are not expected, but suggested it could be replaced by a 21-member ``political executive committee.'' Among the non-voting guests at the congress are former party members expelled after the Soviet invasion of 1968 that crushed the ``Prague Spring'' Communist-led reforms. There are also 40 delegates from the new reformist Communist Democratic Forum, a potential splinter group challenging Urbanek's leadership which submitted a seven point list of demands. Earlier this week, the Democratic Forum spokesman, Rudolf Prevratil, said ``the congress will show whether the movment can live within the party.'' The party was also likely to discuss the presidential elections. Communist Premier Marian Calfa, who left for Moscow today and was therefore not attending the party congress, gave an unprecedented endorsement to Havel's candidacy. The parliament's presidium voted late Tuesday to reconvene the house Dec. 29 at the presidential Hradcany castle to cast a public vote for president. Havel is essentially the only candidate.
